Monaco can be a nice game to casually solo but the real fun comes from running with accomplices. The more thieves racing through the map, getting beaten and shot, the crazier time you will have.   Watch your friends die in horrible places, like the center of a heavily populated dance floor. Plan elaborate rescue missions to recover your friend's corpse from within a crowd of dancing NPCs. Get beat up by the guards as you struggle to recover your fallen comrade. Laugh at how miserably you failed.  10/10

The graphics might take a bit of getting used to but the great soundtrack by Austin Wintory, the intriguing plot, charming characters and wholesome co-op play makes this game pretty good value for money. Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine is a top down 2D heist game where you and 3 other optional players play as different characters with each having their own abilities over 2 main story acts and 2 supplement acts. The first two acts have a large amount of levels where the last two supplement acts only have a handful, however they are difficult. The game encourages team work as the later levels become incredibly difficult and requires lots of practice and runs. This is a perfect team game but also plays very differently solo and is still lots of fun hiding from enemies and trying to figure out the best paths to take or how best to utilize your character's ability in the level. The game is lots of fun and becomes hectic and fast paced when you trip an alarm and you're trying to run away from the enemies!
at first, you're like 'oh god what's goin on' but then it all goes uphill from there

A splendid game to play with friends, Monaco: What's Yours is Mine is a top-down game puzzle-ish co-op game with a simplistic but very pleasing art style. Now, when I say this game is a 'puzzle-ish co-op game', I say that because it's not quite a puzzle game, as it has elements of action to it, but completing each mission can be seen as a 'puzzle' of sorts. I'd say it's a stealth game, but it's not entirely that, either: while stealth can make things easier, blitzing through a room and drawing all eyes to you can work occasionally also. The goal of each level is to steal all trophies before exiting via the escape route, with an added side objective of collecting as many coins as you can to get a higher score. The main obstacles in the game are the guards, who, upon seeing you, chase you down and beat you senseless until you either escape their pursuit or die. When the latter happens, you can get revived by your buds, but doing so leaves you vulnerable for a decent amount of time, so caution is necessary. By default, you have no means of combat, leaving avoidance of threats as the best option. However, there are items that allow you to better deal with threats, like smoke bombs, sleeping darts, guns, and explosives (possibly others I may have missed), of which you can have one equipped at a time, and all of which are replenished by collecting the previously mentioned coins throughout the level. In addition to guards, there are other obstacles, though most of them just draw the attention of the guards so they can go about their merciless beatings of your team. To offer a wider array of methods to deal with the various things between you and your loot, the game has a character system in which each character has a special ability unique to them; there is a very nice diversity of character choice, with each character possibly opening up alternative routes to the objectives. For instance, the Hacker can hack into terminals and disable nearby electronics, such as cameras and laser sensors, the Cleaner can knock guards unconscious when behind them, and the Mole can break through (some) walls. The game is certainly a lot less interesting and enjoyable when playing alone, as it's meant to be a co-op game first and foremost. It has a story mode, and I have no strong feelings regarding the story either way, but the levels are very well-done, generally. The game has a built-in level editor and thus aptly is tied to the Steam Workshop, so when you're finished with the campaign, there are plenty of community levels to peruse as well, a fair amount of which are bound to be substantial and enjoyable.  In short, fantastic little co-op game that's fun, interesting, and worthwhile. I had a blast playing it, and it's probably one of my favorite little indie games (and by 'indie', I mean the real definition of indie—that is, self-published and independent of any larger company; sorry, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ization of that term is killing me) of all time, simply based on how much of a good time I had with it.

It's an excellent game. Playful animation, movement and colours are appealing to the colorblind eyes. ( I am colorblind.) Fun with anyone, or even just yourself. Cute, and pretty easy. Amusing as well with the different kinds of characters used.  It's a 10/10 for me.

It takes a while to get used to, but Monaco is a fun and entertaining game.  I'm not much on stealth ganes, but this one tells a good story, the mechanics are simple enough to learn, the characters are nicely done, and the music (piano) is fantastic.  So I kept at it, began to understand what to do (not much explanation or tutorial in the game), and got myself hooked on the variety and style of gameplay. Time went by very quickly once the basics were learned. And the options available give you a lot of decisions to make.  This one draws you in with initial simplicity, then steps up the challenge at just the right pace. It's fun, it's different, and I would recommend at least giving it a try.

A lot of people seem to be of the opinion that Monaco is only fun when played in Co-Op, and while it's true that the game is at its best in those kinds of frantic multiplayer games, I honestly think the single player version shines just as much-- it just feels like a totally different game. Whereas co-op in Monaco is all about laying out plans and watching them go horribly wrong --and the frantic, off-the-cuff attempts to coordinate efforts to salvage the heist-- in single player, its a slower, more calculated and tactical game, where your lone-wolf status makes heists incredibly tense. The heightened difficulty of launching these heists solo is undercut by the fact that you have multiple lives-- you can play as every member of the team in solo, which allows for players to die in an often advantageous way by allowing one's self to switch characters-- but it still brings a unique challenge to each of the masterfully designed levels. Throw in a killer piano soundtrack that lands somewhere between ragtime and vaudeville, an enjoyably executed (if slight) story that uses unreliable narration for clever effect, and a robust map-maker tool with countless community maps (to say nothing of the recently added 'zombie' mode, a word that normally makes me cringe due to the cultural oversaturation of zombies, but nonetheless makes for an enjoyable variation on the standard gameplay), and you have the most fun multiplayer game of the year.  At the time I'm writing this, Monaco is $2.99 on a flash sale. I got it for 7.50, and I would've paid full price for it if I realized it would be this fun.

Monaco is a rare must-have masterpiece that is beautifully crafted by Pocketwatch Games. The game follows the story of 8 crooks utilizing their unique assets and their assortment of weapons as they take back what is theirs. Monaco takes the player on a top down adventure and the path taken, a decision best left to your crooked ways. The art style and soundtrack lend to the game's exceptional theme and sense of class. Choose between single player or cross-platform multiplayer and play on a variety of campaign maps or challenge yourself with user created custom maps from the Steam Workshop. Worthy of note are the several major content updates that were free of charge. In an era where developers nickle and dime their fans, Pocketwatch Games is doing something right. I only wish that they would consider a sequel. Your Steam library may never be complete without this game.
Excellent top-down heist simulation with unique retro art style and optimized for four player co-op.

My new favorite stealth game. This game has atmosphere out the wazoo and the rock-solid gameplay to keep you coming back even after that wears off. In that sense, it's a lot like Hotline Miami.   The classes all feel different, but you could use any combination and still pull off a mission.  The music is PERFECT. Stealth music instantly and seamlessly transitions to chase music the second you're discovered, which is simply a joy from a visceral and gameplay perspective.  I could go on about this game forever. Buy it! Highly recommended!!!

Monaco is easily one of my favourite games in my big games library. A quirky stealth action, you take the role of 4 characters, at the start, The Locksmith, The Pickpocket, The Lookout and The Cleaner. Each with their own abilities, and hidden abilities, to aid themselves, or their team. You play through and unlock more characters each with their own unique abilites and ways to aid. Honestly this game is best played MP where it can get out of hand and chaotic, which to be honest is where the most fun is. Running from guards desperatly trying to revive your teammates while being careful that dog doesn't get to you, it's really enjoyable. If you are a completionist then best avoid this as to 100% you have to get 4 trophies, they are as followed: completed in SP, completed in MP, completed without dying (or if doing on MP none of you can die) and finally cleaning out the level, which you must do for EVERY level. Some of the later levels get ridiculously hard. So in summary I would definitly reccommend this game and you should buy it, especially because the Dev who made it is a really nice guy.

If you're a fan of local coop and like playing games in the same room as your friends this game should probably be on your shortlist of must haves.

Monaco is a very fun game: you can play in singleplayer mode as well with up to 3 friends using one among 8 characters with different special skills (yes, it's much more fun playing with friends). Every level is pretty much unique and you can approach at it in many different ways, according to the members of your party. Obviously the stealthier the better. At the end of every level your score is based upon the time you spent finishing the level (that is catching the main objectives) to which will be added a penalty that will be as big as he coins you missed during the level.  Artistically speaking, we're dealing with a jewel: your screen will be invaded by any sort of color and the retro style is something simply beatiful.  Base gameplay is already various, but it's additionally enhanced by the presence of the zombie mode which is very difficult, even though I haven't played very much. In addition to what I've already written, there are many interesting community levels which can help you learn the basics of the classes and many tricks.  In the end: I absolutely recommend this game because it's simply one of the best and deep coop experiences you can find.  10/10

A really original take on a video game: case da joint, sneak past the guards, h4xx0r the alarms, and get away with the loot. The variety in obstacles and powers to overcome them is good, though I think that some characters seem underpowered compared to their fellows. I like that it's designed with single and multi-player in mind, but think that the single-player is a bit too frustrating. It really ought to let you swap out characters during the level if you're playing by yourself. As it is, you only get to use a new guy if your current one dies. I've yet to actually suicide in order to do this, but close. There are definitely spots where it gets tough in the later levels, and sneaking by solo is all but impossible. If you want to grab everything, you may wind up brute-forcing an unpleasant amount of stuff. Haven't tried out the multiplayer to date.

An enjoyably arcadey take on the criminal genre that embraces a larger emphasis on stealth than PAYDAY, but a more forgiving view on alerting enemies than Thief. The game contains a ream of both developer and custom-made content, with full Steam Workshop support. Good alone, spectacular with friends.  Positives: + Extremely entertaining, fluid, yet challenging gameplay + A selection of classes that genuinely change the way you play + A fun, arcadey graphics style that communicates information effectively + Seemingly endless content, with four campaigns and Steam Workshop support for user created levels + An easily usable level editor, containing all of the tiles, objects and tools used in the game. + Easily-hosted servers  Negatives: - Occasional sever connectivity issues - A large difficulty spike between the Pickpocket's Story and Fin campaign. - Lack of checkpoints can prove an irritation  Rating: 83%

At first I didn't really 'get' this game or why it was so good. I didn't care about the co-op either, as I figured playing with random people wouldn't be great. Then I found myself playing it all weekend and absolutely loving it, and hugely enjoying co-op with random people as well.  It seems really simple at first, but the game has a lot of depth. You start to realise how many options you have for dealing with the levels, and the levels go from the trivial opening ones to incredibly difficult end ones. The middle levels are wonderful and the later levels are a huge challenge. A good co-op team can help but isn't required.  The people playing the game are properly into it and everyone seems to intuitively understand what each other is doing, and it's a lot of fun.  Highly recommended!

Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Squirrel's seal of approval: Gold  Why I played: One of my irl friends got a four pack so me, him, and 2 other irl friends could play monaco together on release. I will admit that I was surprised by how good this game was.  Should you play: If it is on a sale, it is a great buy. If you like stealth and co-op games this is for you. Even if you don't play much indie games like me, you should have some fun.   Recommended controller input: Keyboard/Mouse, Xbox stylye controller  Pros +Great art style +Great soundtrack +Extremely well balanced classes +Good stealth mechanics +Good UI +Easy to pick up and play +Good controls +Funny dialogue +Good level design +Great co-op +Extremely easy to provide developer input  Cons +Repetitive +Not much fun without friends  Runability Can run on a toaster, trust me, burrito played it xD  Verdict While this game is very fun, it does not last long. I do suspect my in-game time for this won't get much higher anytime soon, but I have to say this game is great. One of the great things about indie games is how it is usually way easier to voice your opinions to developers. In fact, with monaco, I know of some developers' steam accounts, so I can ask them questions or give feedback. It makes me feel like I am helping them achieve something, and it makes me feel good. 9/10

Monaco is wonderfully awesome unique stealth game that is just a blast to play especially with friends. The goal is to successfully pull of a series of heists while avoiding guards and various other traps. You'll be freaking out everytime your friend sets off the alarm AGAIN and caos will ensue. The game rewards you for playing with stealth, but using a weird mix of caos and planning can work out just as well sometimes. There are so many different ways to go through each level, and the experience is really different between single player and multiplayer, so it has a ton of replay value too.

Monaco has the foundations of a great co-op heist game. Each character has a special ability and quirky attitude, and when you have 2-4 people working together, the cooperative stealth in this game truly makes it fun. The music is absolutely delightful to listen to with the push and pull of the cautious environment. There are many different playing options in levels and style of playing too. It definitey has something great going here.  But, there is one thing I find a little annoying and odd. When I started playing, I was expecting there to be some sort of brief on each mission; map layout, special persons, particular weapons/traits, just something to predetermine some strategy. This is a heist game after all.   To be fair though it's not that big of a deal, but it would save me time in having to put up with a rather really slow and overly cautious play through, or, a hectic and rushed one, just so I can get some strategy down.  8/10

This is a pretty fun stealth game and even better with other players. You unlock lots of different characters as you progress through the game. Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine is a 2D game where form a group of four along each character's stories. Playing alone is not recommended, additionaly, there are only a few lobbies to join in(or at least in my region) compared to when it had a ''free day''. It became boring to me after a day because of the lack of lobbies.  Each session has its thrills and a whole lot of vibrant colours, even in screenshots. If you don't find it cheerful, your vision is my concern. As for the audio, I can't really say much; I was too busy collecting coins for my shotgun. As for the missions, I am glad they are assorted. They're not all prison breaks or heists, but I haven't finished the game so I can't really say more than that. I have played it long enough(I think) to say it though.  The game doesn't have an atmosphere as it does not need any(though it would be more impressive if there was) because it is a fast-paced multiplayer, however, every random lobby has a random story; all three of you are in the stairs to the next leve-- wait, three? THREE?   Well, you just found out one of your teammates got shot and now you have to get to him before advancing. One of you decides to do it, only to die in the process too(noob lol), you go ahead and get rushed by three guards, and the last one? Cowering in the ladder. After a minute of trying to convince the last guy, he eventually gets out of his spot and saves all three of you.  But now your score is extremely low, which sucks. True story(Told it in Second-Person View so it wouldn't be that confusing with words).  And so it comes to the generalization:  Gameplay: 19/25 Graphics: 15/25 Concept: 17/25 Presentation: 15/25  66/100 ----------------------------------------- I think you'll like it for the first five days(in raw hours), so yes, I recommend Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine to you, the reader of this review. And please do give feedback so I could make my reviews more readable and helpful  --JustOak

This game is wonderful with friends.   Plan your moves carefully, craft a clever plan to get the goods undetected and then bask in glow of your accomplishment as you pull it off. Or, more often than not, go on a frenzied panic-fuelled run through the level as you try to lose the angry pursuers. And this is the real strength of the game - having your elaborate (or not, as the case may be) plan fall to pieces does not mean it's time to restart. It means it's time to think on your feet. And that's often more fun.  The various classes all distinguish themselves, though some are clearly more or less suited to some levels. The visuals can initially be confusing but it grows on you.

In the beginning you choose between 4 or 5 characters that have each its particular advantages in completing the levels. As you progress through the game you unlock new characters with new capabilities.  Great for teamplay and plan devising. It's a game that works both well for casual and hardcore gamers, I like to play for the fun, not minding to complete the level perfectly, just doing it is fine, but I see teams that are very well planned and are designed to finish the levels in the fastest way possible so that's great too.

Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine is a stealth/action singleplayer & co-op game developed by Pocketwatch Games featuring eight playable characters, each with their own specialty, as well as a lot of levels within the campaigns to keep one busy for hours on end (not including the MANY user-created levels made with the very well-done built-in level creator). Playing the levels with each character is like a different experience on it's own, which doesn't include the experience you and your friends could enjoy with the awesome co-op. Add to that Monaco can be (and is for me) a VERY addicting game with a nice soundtrack that fits completely and you have yourself a game worth every penny. Buy it now or it'll be your loss!

For me Monaco is the Game of the Year 2013 and it's also one of the best games I've ever played. Whether you like to play games casually or competitively, Monaco delivers them big time. Just when you have 100% completed the game with your sneaky and stealthy strategies you will find out that there is also a lively speedrunning community which tries to push quickness to it's limits all the time and all over again. You cannot even think of how competitive this game is after you have grinded one level for hours just to get that world record. Moreover, if you have friends to play with the fun is suddenly doubled. Planning crazy heists or speedruns with friends absurdly pleasant and after you get fed up with your constantly dying team mates you can turn them into foes in multiple PvP maps!  All in all, Monaco is tons of fun and laugh no matter how you play it. It's definitely worth couple of bucks (and it's on sale ALL THE FREAKING TIME) and for me one of the best video games I've ever witnessed.

This game is awesome. The gameplay, the music, the pixelized astetics, everything. Granted, this game is best played with friends, but if you have the patience to get through the game, each level you finish becomes one you can play with whoever is hosting that level.  The Heists are fun and have a good learning curve. You can mess around all you want at the start, and even the slightest wrong move will kill you in the last levels. My favorite aspect of the game is the PvP. One on one, the gameplay is very tactical, and stratigic, if you're killed holding all the trophies, then you've basically lost. If you have the fortune to get in a lobby with two or three other people, then a riot will ensue, unless you've honed your skills, you will be constantly killed, and constanty be killing the other players. Matches can last a long time and be utterly epic when you win. Like others have said, get the four pack, and share it with your friends, or if you don't have any, just wait around for open lobbys to pop up. You won't regret it. (The music is epic too)

I absolutely adore this game, and the sort of chaos that ensues when you play with friends. To really get the best experience, I feel like you need to play this with a group of friends locally, either couch coop or local lan. One of my favorite memories was watching as three of my group carefully tried to sneak through a building, while our fourth got into trouble deep into secure territory, forcing us to devise a plan to save his ♥♥♥, and proceeding to get into messier and messier situation until we simply lost.  There are just a few issues I'm finding in trying to enjoy this game:  1. The game is not very fun by yourself. 2. The game takes a while to get interesting, but if you skip the early levels, the mechanics can be confusing to new players. 3. Even so, there are a lot of subtle mechanics that can be lost on players still adjusting to the game. 4. I can't find anybody who enjoys the game locally to play with.

I bought this game quite a while ago due to the urging of my friends. Those were good times when we had no idea what to do, we would get the ♥♥♥♥ beaten out of us, we had no idea what 'stealth' meant, and we bickered over who was the best Cleaner or Gentleman, etc. This game is certainly a diamond in the rough. The graphics were at first a turn-off for me and the lack of multiplayer lobbies also made the game grim.  However, I still come back to this game from time-to-time. Maybe find a few friends to play or replay this with. I pick up more secrets and strategies with each run. I learn and I teach the art of stealth, robbery, and general conniving. This game can be as fast and as slow as you want it to be with the call of speed running beckoning you. Whether you just aim to complete the level or 'clean out' the level, you'll definitely be in for a riveting ride.

The simple pixel art belies a suprisingly cerebral and challenging game which has to be approached in vastly different ways based on the character class you choose. Each of the eight classes has a unique ability that is extremely useful in many circumstances and almost worthless in others, and you'll be switching between them as you try to work your way through the game's four acts. The most fun to be had is with three friends playing together over voice chat where you can coordinate your moves to pull off the perfect heist, or call out your buddy who trips the alarm just as you were about to steal the jewels. If you've ever watched a heist movie and thought to yourself, 'I want to do that,' then this is the game for you.

I recieved this game as a gift a while ago, and from around 90m of co-op gameplay, I cannot stand this game, not one bit.  I liked the layout of the menus and their bright intense color on black, contrasting the giant pixels to the max. However, the gameplay in my opinion is extremely repetitive, and the game kind of 'forces' you to stealth the joint. In this I mean how you may have a shotgun, you can go in and blow someone to their pixely skeleton, however note that you can only use it once, before having to collect 10 stupid coins to load another use into your weapon/tool. And by the time I collected 10 coins, I had about 20 stupid Watchmen following me, tripping lasers as I ran, and doctors shooting me with tranquilizer crossbows, which led to me being beaten to death with the deadly forks the Watchmen hold. Sure, you can try to hide in a bush/vent/tree, but by the time I went in one, they followed me to the bush and happened to poke the bush with their forks, leading me to my instant death. The music, in my opinion, is awful, just sounding like an extremely sped up piano ballad, or better yet a 2-year-old banging their hands and arms on every key possible.  The graphics are squares. I think everything is a square. Your body is a big square, with a smaller square (the head, which stupidly bobbles left and right any time you move your mouse), and two little squares (the arms) on the side of the big square. Despite this I do like the lighting effects and post-processing. The animations are like pixel ragdolls.. It's strange. There are different characters to choose from, all with different abilities. I thought that it was cool, being able to have a specialty and all. You start off with 4 at the beginning, and get more as you progress through the campaign. Also, I just want to throw out there that if you want to go up a staircase, ladder, etc., you have to 'prepare' it first, and once it's 'prepared', you need to wait for ALL players to go there in order to go up. Hated waiting.  Overall? 4/10.. Others may like this game, but I sure as hell don't. I'll give them points for originality, but that's it. It's not my kind of game.

Theoretically this game is a planning, sneaking and making a successful casual heist for money together with your friends while communicating actively with each character supporting each other.  In reality this game is 30 seconds of walking around and trying to plan, and suddenly it's all chaos, running around finding hiding places, you loose track of your friends, if anyone chats or speaks over mic it's just 'what is happening' 'where are you' 'where do we go'. Quickly you just find yourself playing your own game, reviving friends, doing something that will hopefully help team to reach the goal... There isnt really much timing with your friends.  The game runs too fast to make strategic decisions. And maybe it was intended to be just casual or for youngsters on speed but if you are someone looking for some coop that requires using brains, I can't recommend it. Its very casual and maybe our expectations were too high for strategic team play.  Maybe we are just too bad in this game. I never quite fully grasped the enjoyment factor for this game. But it might be a good game for you, it´s not for old farts for sure.  Sometimes the teamplay does work, where you proceed together with your friends, but it doesn´t really stand much pressure and turns into solo too easy, where getting the pack together takes a lot of effort.
